item.title: Sending fake events to an AWT Panel (full running code example included)
item.dc:creator: @GenoDemoN GenoDemoN
item.description:
@GenoDemoN wrote:

[quote=“newbiehacker, post:22, topic:3754”][me=uberhacker]isn’t going to school tommorow and has lots of free time :)[/me][br][size=1]Posted at: June 22, 2006, 04:09:16 pm[/size][hr]okay, the hierarchy of the WebBrowser class is

java.lang.Object
  extended by java.awt.Component
      extended by java.awt.Canvas
          extended by org.jdesktop.jdic.browser.WebBrowser

I don’t think that Component’s or Canvas’ have their own mose and key listening methods, and also, dispatchEvent throws an error (I’m guessing this is what you tried).
webBrowser != null and a newly created KeyEveny can’t be null either so my assumption is that they don’t have whatever it is a Canvas needs to dispatch an event.

here’s the lame code I tried and it’s output

System.out.println(webBrowser == null);
webBrowser.dispatchEvent(new KeyEvent(webBrowser, 0, System.currentTimeMillis(), KeyEvent.VK_A, 'a'));

OUTPUT:
false
Exception in thread "AWT-EventQueue-0" java.lang.NullPointerException
        at java.awt.DefaultKeyboardFocusManager.processKeyEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Component.dispatchEventImpl(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Component.dispatchEvent(Unknown Source)
        at ClientExample.actionPerformed(ClientExample.java:103)
        at javax.swing.AbstractButton.fireActionPerformed(Unknown Source)
        at javax.swing.AbstractButton$Handler.actionPerformed(Unknown Source)
        at javax.swing.DefaultButtonModel.fireActionPerformed(Unknown Source)
        at javax.swing.DefaultButtonModel.setPressed(Unknown Source)
        at javax.swing.plaf.basic.BasicButtonListener.mouseReleased(Unknown Sour
ce)
        at java.awt.Component.processMouseEvent(Unknown Source)
        at javax.swing.JComponent.processMouseEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Component.processEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Container.processEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Component.dispatchEventImpl(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Container.dispatchEventImpl(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Component.dispatchEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.LightweightDispatcher.retargetMouseEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.LightweightDispatcher.processMouseEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.LightweightDispatcher.dispatchEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Container.dispatchEventImpl(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Window.dispatchEventImpl(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Component.dispatchEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.EventQueue.dispatchEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpOneEventForFilters(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpEventsForFilter(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpEventsForHierarchy(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpEvents(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.pumpEvents(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.EventDispatchThread.run(Unknown Source)

[hr]k[/quote]

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars


^shows them adding window events to the canvas
since then they have added mouse listeners to it.
they move them around, don’t send events to the wrong things

1150844454671 queued java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_RELEASED,(327,272),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=1] on canvas2
1150844454687 sent java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_RELEASED,(327,272),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=1] on canvas2
1150844454687 queued java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_CLICKED,(327,272),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=1] on canvas2
1150844454734 sent java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_CLICKED,(327,272),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=1] on canvas2

1151071167375 out java.awt.event.FocusEvent[FOCUS_GAINED,permanent,opposite=null] on canvas4

java.lang.Object
  extended by java.awt.Component
      extended by java.awt.Canvas
          extended by org.jdesktop.jdic.browser.WebBrowser

I don’t think that Component’s or Canvas’ have their own mose and key listening methods, and also, dispatchEvent throws an error (I’m guessing this is what you tried).
webBrowser != null and a newly created KeyEveny can’t be null either so my assumption is that they don’t have whatever it is a Canvas needs to dispatch an event.

here’s the lame code I tried and it’s output

System.out.println(webBrowser == null);
webBrowser.dispatchEvent(new KeyEvent(webBrowser, 0, System.currentTimeMillis(), KeyEvent.VK_A, 'a'));

OUTPUT:
false
Exception in thread "AWT-EventQueue-0" java.lang.NullPointerException
        at java.awt.DefaultKeyboardFocusManager.processKeyEvent(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Component.dispatchEventImpl(Unknown Source)
        at java.awt.Component.dispatchEvent(Unknown Source)

item.dc:creator: @Galook Galook
item.description:
@Galook wrote:

im not so sure you could if you didnt know swing basically comes from awt…

java.lang.Object
java.awt.Component
java.awt.Container
java.awt.Window
java.awt.Frame
javax.swing.JFrame

^^^ thats Jframe and all of its superclasses… notice it directly extends java.awt.Frame, but yeah… gl mopar if you havent already figured it out

i cant help either unfortunately… ive never really been that great with making programs look nice for other people

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @iwasinmoparseas101cl iwasinmoparseas101class
item.description:
@iwasinmoparseas101cl wrote:

how are you figuring that swing is based in AWT? because they are in different packages:

java.awt.;
javax.swing.;

Have you figured out the source of your problem? once you pose up more code I could be definitely of more assistance. It’s just hard to see everything when you only give us a couple lines of code

item.title: Sending fake events to an AWT Panel (full running code example included)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“RegeX, post:8, topic:3754”]Ugh. I can’t believe I didn’t suggest this before.

Just post events to the AWT Event queue duder.
Something like:

java.awt.Toolkit.getToolkit().getSystemEventQueue().postEvent(AWTEvent theEvent)

Or something like that. I haven’t done this in ages, TBH I can’t remember a thing =P[/quote]

I was going to try that, but since even swing is based on AWT wouldnt it try to send the event to my jframe?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @RegeX RegeX
item.description:
@RegeX wrote:

Ugh. I can’t believe I didn’t suggest this before.

Just post events to the AWT Event queue duder.
Something like:

java.awt.Toolkit.getToolkit().getSystemEventQueue().postEvent(AWTEvent theEvent)

Or something like that. I haven’t done this in ages, TBH I can’t remember a thing =P
